author: David Mollett
title: Equus panel takes flak from breeder over fillies’ exclusion | Other Sport
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK RACEHORSE owner and breeder Peter de Beyer has slated the panel of the Equus Awards regarding their nominees for the category of Champion Three-Year-Old Filly.
The awards were handed out at a banquet in Kempton Park last week with Mike de Kock’s filly, Alboran Sea, voted Champion Three-Year-Old Filly.
While De Beyer says he is not unhappy with this decision — "although it is very difficult to compare a sprinter against a middle-distance runner" — the exclusion of his filly Siren’s Call and Inara has his blood boiling.
In a letter to the industry’s paper, The Sporting Post, De Beyer says "the big shock is that dual Grade 1 winner Inara is not a nominee".
"I think this is the first time in history that a dual Grade 1 winner in any Equus award category has been left off the list of nominees.
"I am disappointed Siren’s Call also didn’t make the list despite coming within a whisker of winning the Wilgerbosdrift Triple Tiara," he said.
Siren’s Call certainly played her part in Sean Tarry capturing his first trainer’s title with the filly earning more than R2.5m during the season.
Her victories also provided a huge boost for her sire, Elusive Fort, who is not as fashionable a sire as the big names such as Captain Al, Dynasty and Trippi.
Captain Al just edged out Trippi and Dynasty for the Champion Sire award, rounding off a magnificent season for Klawervlei Stud.
The stud managed to beat fierce rival Summerhill Stud for the second year running.
The cherry on the top for Klawervlei Stud is the news that Captain Al’s son, Captain Of All, is the world’s 17th highest-rated horse, according to an August 13 press release from Longines.
Most pundits felt the Equus panel got it right with their selection of Futura as the 2014-15 Horse of the Year. The four-year-old is co-owned by a leading bloodstock consultant who enjoyed an outstanding season as he also manages several top stallions including the big three last term — Captain Al, Trippi and Dynasty.
Interestingly, when it came to the Cape annual awards, held jointly by the Racing Association and Cape Breeders Club, it was Dennis Drier’s sprinter, Captain Of All, who got the award for Horse of the Year.
As was the case with the national awards, Futura was voted Horse of the Year in the Cape Racing awards section. They gave an exceptional achievement award to trainer Stan Elley, who retired from the training ranks at the end of July.
Robert Bloomberg, a legal expert and prominent owner for many years, was also rewarded with an industry service award.
